description:
Human betaherpesvirus 6B (HHV-6B) is a member of the Herpesviridae family, specifically the Betaherpesvirinae subfamily. It is a DNA virus that primarily infects human hosts and is known to cause a variety of clinical manifestations, including roseola infantum (also known as sixth disease or exanthem subitum), a common childhood illness characterized by a distinctive rash.

HHV-6B is a ubiquitous virus, with a seroprevalence of over 90% in the general population. The virus is primarily transmitted through saliva and can be acquired during early childhood, often leading to asymptomatic primary infection. However, in some cases, the virus can reactivate later in life, particularly in immunocompromised individuals, and cause more severe clinical manifestations.

The genome of HHV-6B is a linear, double-stranded DNA molecule, encoding a variety of proteins involved in viral replication, immune evasion, and host cell manipulation. The virus primarily targets and infects CD4+ T cells, a critical component of the human immune system, but can also infect other cell types, including glial cells in the central nervous system.

HHV-6B has been associated with a range of neurological and hematological disorders, including encephalitis, multiple sclerosis, and lymphoproliferative disorders. The mechanisms by which the virus contributes to these conditions are still under investigation, but ongoing research aims to elucidate the complex interplay between HHV-6B and the host's immune system and nervous system.
